title: Golovkin survives Derevyanchko via decision to reclaim...
text:
Gennadiy Golovkin survived a heated back-and-forth bout with a victory via unanimous decision over Sergiy Derevyanchenko on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden in New York to reclaim his championship belt.

Golovkin (40-1-1, 35 KOs), of Kazakhstan, regained the vacant IBF world middleweight title, after losing it to Canelo Alvarez via split decision in September 2018. The 37-year-old remained perfect against all opponents other than Alvarez, whom Golovkin also drew with in a September 2017 bout for the same belt.

Judge Frank Lombardi scored Saturday's fight 114-113, while Eric Marlinski and Kevin Morgan both scored it 115-112. The close result proved to be a surprise after Golovkin opened with a fury, dropping Derevyanchenko in the first round with a hard right and opening up a cut by his opponent's right eye with a left in the second round.

But the Ukrainian Derevyanchenko, known as "The Technician," came back strong, taking Rounds 3-6 on two of the three judges' cards. Both fighters had strong moments down the stretch, with no unanimous scores given between Rounds 8-11, but Golovkin claimed the final round on all three cards.

"I told you, he's a very tough guy. This is huge experience for me," Golovkin said afterward. "Right now, I understand I need more. ... I feel this was not an easy fight for me. This was a tough fight."

Derevyanchenko, 33, fell to 13-2 (10 KOs) in his career. His only previous loss came via split decision to Daniel Jacobs in an October 2018 fight for the same title.

--Field Level Media
